choices.text: Tensor tympani pulls the foot plate out of the round window
Protects the cochlea from damaging vibrations caused by excessively loud sound

questions.text: Which among the following is true about the attenuation reflex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The attenuation reflex, also known as the acoustic reflex, is an involuntary muscle contraction that occurs in the middle ear in response to loud sounds.
  • Its primary role is protective; it reduces the transmission of sound energy to the inner ear, particularly to the cochlea, in order to prevent damage from loud noises.
  • When a loud sound is transmitted through the ossicular system, the attenuation reflex occurs after a latent period of about 40 milliseconds, reducing cochlear damage from excessive vibration.

This reflex involves two muscles:

  • Stapedius muscle: contracts to pull the stapes away from the oval window, reducing the movement of the stapes.
  • Tensor tympani muscle: contracts to pull the malleus medially, increasing tension on the tympanic membrane and reducing its vibration.

Together, these actions dampen sound transmission, especially low-frequency sounds.

Explanation of other options:

Tensor tympani pulls the foot plate out of the round window (Option A): This is incorrect because the tensor tympani attaches to the handle of the malleus, not the stapes footplate. The footplate belongs to the stapes and fits into the oval window, not the round window.

Stapedius pulls the manubrium medially (Option B): This is incorrect because the stapedius is attached to the stapes, not the manubrium (handle of the malleus). It pulls the stapes posteriorly to reduce movement at the oval window.

questions.text: Which of the following in the ear regulates the pressure in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The eustachian tube plays a critical role in regulating pressure in the middle ear by connecting it to the nasopharynx (the upper part of the throat behind the nose). Its functions include:
    • Equalising the air pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane (eardrum), especially during swallowing, yawning, or altitude changes such as flying.
    • Allowing drainage of normal secretions from the middle ear into the throat.

The Eustachian tube

  • Equalises pressure across the tympanic membrane
  • Protects the middle ear from reflux
  • Clears out middle ear secretions

Dysfunction affects all three and leads to:

  • Pain
  • Muffled sound
  • Balance problems
  • Infections (otitis media)

Explanation of other options:

Tympanic membrane (Option B): The tympanic membrane vibrates in response to sound waves but does not regulate pressure.

Oval window (Option C ): The oval window receives vibrations from the stapes and transmits them to the inner ear; it has no role in pressure regulation.

Round window (Option D): The round window allows movement of fluid within the cochlea to accommodate vibrations from the oval window, but it does not regulate middle ear pressure.

Convexity of the tympanic membrane towards the middle ear cavity

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for the impedance matching mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear is essential for efficient sound transmission from the air-filled external environment to the fluid-filled inner ear.
  • Without this mechanism, most of the sound energy would be reflected at the air-fluid interface, leading to significant hearing loss.
  • Three factors contribute to impedance matching:
    1. Ossicular lever system: The malleus and incus function as a lever, amplifying the force transmitted to the stapes. This lever action increases the efficiency of sound conduction. (Option A)
    2. Surface area difference: The tympanic membrane is much larger than the footplate of the stapes. This difference concentrates sound energy, thereby increasing the pressure exerted at the oval window. (Option B)
    3. Convexity of the tympanic membrane: The curved shape of the tympanic membrane allows it to act like a funnel, directing and focusing sound vibrations toward the ossicles. (Option C)
  • Together, these three factors ensure that sound is transferred effectively from air to fluid, preventing energy loss due to impedance mismatch and thereby enhancing auditory sensitivity.

choices.text: Endolymph has a similar composition to extracellular fluid (ECF)
K+ is continuously being secreted into the endolymph
Endolymph has a high Na+ concentration

questions.text: A physiology student is studying the composition of cochlear fluids. He learns that the ionic gradients maintained in the cochlea are essential for generating the endocochlear potential, which plays a key role in sound transduction. Which of the following statements regarding the endolymphatic potential is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The endolymph in the cochlear duct has an unusual ionic composition, with high potassium (K+) and low sodium (Na+).
  • This composition is actively maintained by the stria vascularis, which continuously secretes K+ into the endolymph.
  • As a result, the endolymph develops a positive electrical potential of about +80 mV, called the endocochlear potential.
  • This potential provides the driving force for K+ to flow into hair cells during sound stimulation, allowing depolarisation and efficient auditory transduction.

Explanation of other options:

Endolymph has a similar composition to ECF (Option A): Endolymph is very different from extracellular fluid. Unlike ECF, which is high in Na+ and low in K+, endolymph has the opposite composition and resembles intracellular fluid.

Endolymph has a high Na+ concentration (Option C): Endolymph contains very little Na+. Instead, perilymph, which surrounds the membranous labyrinth, has high Na+ and low K+, resembling ECF.

choices.text: Low-frequency sound causes maximal activation of the basilar membrane near the base of the cochlea
High-frequency sound activates the basilar membrane near the apex of the cochlea
Determination of sound frequencies is known as the place principle

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding sound frequencies reaching the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The place principle (place theory) describes how different sound frequencies are encoded in the cochlea. Different regions of the basilar membrane respond maximally to different frequencies, a phenomenon known as tonotopic organisation.
  • High-frequency sounds cause maximal displacement near the base of the cochlea (narrow and stiff region).
  • Low-frequency sounds cause maximal displacement near the apex of the cochlea (a wide and flexible region). Thus, the brain determines the pitch of sound based on which region of the basilar membrane is activated.

The place principle is the frequency coding mechanism of the cochlea:



Explanation of other options:

Low-frequency sound causes maximal activation of the basilar membrane near the base of the cochlea (Option A): Low-frequency sounds do not activate the base of the cochlea. They stimulate the apex.

High-frequency sound activates the basilar membrane near the apex of the cochlea (Option B): High-frequency sounds do not activate the apex. They stimulate the base.

questions.text: A 24-year-old is advised to undergo hearing tests before being appointed for a job in a factory. On testing, his bone conduction is less than air conduction in both ears. Which of the following tests helps to identify this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Rinne Test compares air conduction (AC) with bone conduction (BC) using a tuning fork.
  • Normal finding: AC > BC (seen in normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss).
  • Conductive hearing loss: BC > AC.
  • In this case, the patient had AC > BC in both ears, which is a normal finding. Thus, the Rinne test is the appropriate and specific test to identify this condition.

Explanation of other options:

Weber Test (Option B): The Weber test checks lateralisation of sound and helps differentiate between unilateral conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, but it does not directly compare AC and BC.

Schwabach Test (Option C): This test compares the patient's bone conduction with that of the examiner. It is less commonly used and is not specific for comparing air vs. bone conduction.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient visited the physician due to a reduced sense of hearing. On examination, the physician diagnosed him with conductive type of deafness. Among the following, which is not a cause of deafness in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Conductive hearing loss occurs when sound conduction through the external or middle ear is impaired, preventing efficient transmission of vibrations to the inner ear.
  • Chronic exposure to loud sound is not a cause of conductive deafness.
  • Instead, it leads to sensorineural hearing loss due to irreversible damage to the cochlear hair cells in the organ of Corti.
  • This type of hearing loss affects the inner ear and cannot be corrected by surgery or conventional medication.

Explanation of other options:

Otitis media (Option A): A common cause of conductive hearing loss, where fluid or infection in the middle ear reduces vibration conduction to the inner ear.

Otosclerosis (Option C): Abnormal bony overgrowth around the stapes footplate interferes with its movement at the oval window, producing conductive hearing loss.

Tympanic membrane perforation (Option D): A rupture or hole in the eardrum reduces sound transmission efficiency, leading to conductive hearing loss.

Key takeaway:

Common Causes:

  • Conductive causes: Otitis media, otosclerosis, tympanic membrane perforation, impacted wax, etc.
  • Sensorineural causes: Noise-induced hair cell damage, presbycusis, ototoxic drugs, and acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: Which of the following areas is involved in the storage of olfactory memories?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The olfactory system projects to multiple cortical regions, each having distinct roles in olfactory processing.
  • The entorhinal cortex is particularly important for the storage of olfactory memories, as it integrates olfactory inputs with the hippocampal formation, which plays a central role in memory consolidation.

Explanation of other options:

Neocortex (Option A): Specifically, the orbitofrontal and frontal cortical areas are involved in the conscious discrimination and perception of odours, but they do not function as primary memory storage sites for olfaction.

Amygdala (Option B): This region links olfactory stimuli with emotional and motivational responses, such as fear or pleasure associated with particular smells. It plays a modulatory role but is not the main site of olfactory memory storage.

Piriform cortex (Option C): This is the primary olfactory cortex and is strongly activated by sniffing and direct odour detection. It is important for initial odour identification but not long-term olfactory memory storage.

Key takeaway:

  • Entorhinal cortex → olfactory memory storage
  • Neocortex (orbitofrontal) → odour discrimination
  • Amygdala & hypothalamus → emotional and motivational response to odours
  • Piriform cortex → primary processing during sniffing/odour detection

questions.text: Which of the following nerves carries taste sensations from the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Taste sensation from different regions of the oral cavity and pharynx is carried by distinct cranial nerves:
    • The chorda tympani nerve (branch of the facial nerve, CN VII) transmits taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) transmits taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    • The vagus nerve (CN X) carries taste sensation from the pharynx and epiglottis.
  • Thus, for the pharynx specifically, the vagus nerve is responsible.
  • All afferent fibres conveying taste sensations synapse in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. From there, projections ascend to the thalamus and eventually to the gustatory cortex in the insula and frontal operculum for conscious perception of taste.

Explanation of other options:

Chorda tympani (Option A): This nerve supplies taste fibres only from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not from the pharynx.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option B): It conveys taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue, not the pharynx.
